ABOLISHING ENGLISH COMPOSITION

It has come to our attention that it is the plan of the administration to drop English Composition from -the list of courses
offered to freshmen in 1928-29. This year a partial step in that
direction was taken when entering students were required to take
an examination in composition, which, if passed with a grade of
7.5 or better, served to absolve the student from taking the course.
About one hundred and twenty-five freshmen were required to
take the course.
These one hundred and twenty-five men, with very few exceptions, need the course in composition, and need it badly. The
quality of their work in English, according to the instructors, is
definitely poor.
We can say with assurance that if any of these freshmen were
allowed to receive a degree with their present ability to use the
English language, the University would be distinctly disgraced.
Of course, it is possible that a fairly large proportion of them will
never be graduated, but it is hardly fair either to the men who
will receive degrees or to the University itself to deprive them of
the advanced training in English. It is easy enough to maintain
that they should come to college fully prepared, but if they are
not prepared, it is up to the University to provide the necessary
training.
The present system is perfectly adequate. The men who can
pass the preliminary examination are not burdened with having
to take English Composition, but to assume that all entering
students, regardless of their intelligence or their preparation in
other subjects, are adequately prepared in English, would be a
great mistake. Too many freshmen need English Composition
to permit its being abolished.

It is some time since I resolved to
cease the practice of penning pernicious rot for public perusal, but
after reading an article in the
NEWS-LETTER of February 28, I
feel the urge to enter some sort of
defense of these vile fraternity boys
who hate each other and do nothing but figure. out ways to cut each
other's throats in gentlemanly ways.
The bad feeling between chapters
is easily explained—it is a conceit—if I may use the term of each
individual that he may improve his
own standing by declaiming to the
world at large that such-and-such
is a crowd of loafers, drunks or
what have you. If asked for his
confidential opinion of the same
body he would have no complaint
except, possibly, against a few individuals whom he would hold in
the same contempt, fraternity men
or otherwise.
Perhaps the Alphas are hig-hat
or the Sigmas are drunks—did you
ever consider the fact that the former may have reason for their lofty
attitude and the latter may be able
to pay bootleggers' prices and the
criticism of these groups may be
caused by jealousy?
I am quite sure that the abolition
of fraternities would have no affect
on the present condition, for a man
must have companions, and since it
is obviously impossible to associate
with the entire student body one
must limit himself to a selected
group of men with whom he at least
fancies himself happy. That this
is true is proved by the men on the
'campus who are not affiliated with
any fraternity. They have their
groups and are no doubt influenced
by each other as much as their unfortunate mates who are members
of an organized brotherhood. The
conditions at Hopkins are not conducive to the fostering of a type for
any one fraternity. The real influence in this direction becomes
strong only when the majority of
the brothers live under one roof, eat
at the same table and wear each
other's clothes.
II

HAGERSTOWN VERSUS NORFOLK
In abandoning its Norfolk concert for the trip to Hagerstown
and Chambersburg, the Musical Club has acted very wisely. The
Norfolk trip never had been a success, either from a financial
standpoint or from the point of view of the applause and appreciation received; the Hagerstown and Ch'ambersburg audiences, on
the other hand, were most enthusiastic and supported the concerts
surprisingly well.
It stands to reason, after all, that the smaller towns offer a
more fertile field for the presentations of the club. In the first
place, the annual trip of the Geology I class has established a
reputation for Hopkins students that probably did much for the
Musical Club's cause. In the second place, the relative scarcity
of decent entertainment in small towns gives the club a better
chance to draw large crowds. It is far better to be able to hang
out the "S. R. 0." sign in Hagerstown than to play to an empty
house in Norfolk.

ANOTHER ACHIEVEMENT
Another chapter in the history of the achievements of Hopkins
men has been written at the site of the lost city of Olynthus,
recently discovered by Dr. David M. Robinson, professor of
Archaeology at this University. ; Dr. Robinson, on leave of absence for a year, has made a discovery which may prove to be of
inestimable value to students of Greek civilization all over the
world. The NEWS-LETTER takes this opportunity to congratulate
him in the name of the student body.
The NEWS-LETTER is pleased to announce the election of Gus
Burke, '31, as assistant business manager.

As for the corruption of the campus by fraternity politics—there
would be no less mud thrown or
no better men elected to the various
offices than at present if the elections
were removed from the influence
of fraternities.. Instead of a political deal being made, the hero of the
hour would be elected and he would
be just as incompetent — if not
more so—than our present afflictions. And think of the valuable
experience in fooling the public our
upperclassmen will receive, not to
mention the thrill of believing
they've put one over on the supposedly unsuspecting campus. Let
the boys have their fun.
Basically the fraternities do no
harm. We pledge allegiance to our

brotherhood and swear to .bring it
to perfection, making it a paradise
on earth that no one on being asked
to join could refuse. Those who
make no such pledges miss the
thrill of righteousness that comes
from the mere oath. We come into
close companionship with bad boys
who have been around and know
all the ropes—learning in our
Freshman year the things that the
unfettered non-fraternity men consume their first there in learning.
We hate all who are not pledged to
the same ideals as we, and one fraternity man cannot pass another
on the campus without a malicious
sneer and a muttered "Cad"—yet I
will venture to say that a fraternity
man has as many or more friends
or at least cordial relationships with
his fellow-students as the non-fraternity man. Why? Because a
man feels that he should do something for his fraternity, however
small the contribution, and the
best way is to work for some activity. Here he meets men of other
groups, and if he is any kind of a
man he make friends. If he is the
opposite type—would he be any
better if he were outside the baneful influence of a fraternity?
Of course, all the good men are
not- taken into fraternities. I could
name sonic fine fellows during the
last five years that have received
their degrees without a jeweled pin
decorating their manly chests. Some
from personal reasons have refused
and others have been overlooked.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 6, 1928

The Children Enjoy
Themselves.
Mr. Chairman, honorable judges,
worthy opponents and gentlemen:
A sad misnomer, that last, as applied to most of the individuals
who made up the audience for the
Adams debate at the recent assembly. Gentlemen? Goats and monkeys!
But boys will be boys, you say,
and we shouldn't call them names.
Indulgence is the key-note. The
youngsters must have their fling
and little minds, like murder, will
out.
Six students, after a good bit of
serious preparation, engage in the
more or less valuable exercise Of
debating, valuable in so' far as it
gives the individual good practice
in learning to think clearly on his
_feet, to sharpen his mental alertness and to marshal thoughts in an
effective and orderly manner. They
are competing for a prize of. books.
Assuming, by a curious quirk of
optimism, that they will be listened
to, the debaters get up to. make
their respective deliveries. Before'
the third speaker has concluded his
arguments, the hall is in a kind of
mild uproar. For the youngsters
are at play, and what bleak reformer would dare advocate corking up
the bubbling spir.its of youth? Who
talks of good manners when good
fellows get together?
While the man on the platform is
struggling to get all his points articulated within the brief time allowed each competitor, groups in
various parts of the room are putting their heads together and having a great time of it, cracking
jokes and giggling. Let them prattle away: there is a certain zest in
the collective breaking of rules of
courtesy, the attractiveness of the
forbidden. And, after all, why
should they listen to a lot of spout-

EXPRESSED IN DRESS AT "POW-WOW"
The Junior POW-WOW, the
name designating this year's fracas, will be held—take heed—on
the Prairie bounded by the ancient
walls of the old Civil Engineering
Building on the evening of March
16. Knives and six-shooters will
be in order as well as popguns and
cap pistols—but machine guns, due
to the Chicago monopoly, are absolutely prohibited.
There is no limit upon the kind
of costume to be worn providing
they smack somewhat of- the wild
and wooly spirit of the Golden
West (See Adventure Magazine).
You can be anything from a prairie
dog to a sunset, or from Chief Pie-

Eyed of the bootleg district of
Moklahoma, Indian Territory, to
Wild Bill Hiccup of two-gun fame.
But, Mah Gawd! Mabel, I
haven't reported to you upon the
tax to be extracted from the exchequer of every cowboy. So boys
get out the pouch of gold dust and
weigh off a few nuggets amounting
to $3.00, provided you will be accompanied by a squaw, or $2.00 if
you intend to fight all by yourself.
And oh! that music—the very
best in town—well little readers if
the broomstick doesn't jump over
the back fence, the bunny gentlemen
will tell you more anon. Pleasant
dreams and read up on "How to Be
a Cowboy" or "What Have You at
the Junior POW-WOW."

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 6, 1928

DR. MILES ONLY MAN IN
STATE TO HOLD C. M. H.
Congressional Medal of Honor
Awarded Professor in 1919
Investigations carried on recently
by several Baltimore newspapers
has revealed the interesting fact
that Dr. L. Wardlaw Miles, collegiate professor of English at Johns
Hopkins University, is the only
man now residing in Maryland who
holds the Congressional Medal of
Honor.
Lead Sally

Captain Miles volunteered to lead
his company in a sally against an
enemy trench near the Aisne Canal
and, while attacking at the head of
his men, was struck five times by
machine-gun bullets. The first shot
grazed him and the second two
were direct hits. Captain Miles
still "carried on" until two more
wounds brought him to earth. Then
he forced his men to place him on
a stretcher and carry him forward
so that he could continue to direct
operations.
"For bravery alone and beyond
the call of duty in action with, the
enemy near Revillon, France, September 4, 1918," Captain Miles was
awarded the Congressional Medal
of Honor by act of Congress.
Dr. Miles was a professor at
Princeton, when war broke out. He
enlisted and was trained at the officers training school at Plattsburg.

Hullabaloo Rounding
Rapidly Into Shape
With most of the fraternity material collected and with a large
amount of the senior write-ups and
pictures in, the Hullabaloo is slowly
becoming complete.
Each fraternity has been assessed
fifty-four dollars this year. It has
been estimated that this amount
will cover the cost of four pages;
two pages of engraving and two
pages of printing. This assessment
is ten dollars more than that of last
year, and has occasioned much adverse criticism among the Greeks.

FIRE

Drink

In Paris Hospital

Captain Miles first met the enemy
in Lorraine where, during the entire engagement, he calmly smoked
his pipe and surveyed the conduct
of his raw recruits in battle. After
being awarded the division citations
for this action, Captain Miles fell
sick and went to a hospital in
Paris, where he regained his health.
Back at the front once more,
Captain Miles' troops were attacked
and caught in wire entanglements.
It was at this point that Captain
Miles distinguished himself so
nobly.
His citation reads: "Captain
Miles volunteered to lead his company in a hazardous attack on a
commanding trench position • near
the Aisne Canal. Other troops had
failed. His company met with intense machine gun fire, against
which it had no artillery resistence.
Captain Miles cut a passage
through enemy wire entanglements.
He was wounded five times with
machine gun bullets, but instead of
giving up had himself placed on
a stretcher and carried forward to
the enemy trench to direct the company. His courage and inspiration
enabled his men to hold the hostile
position and consolidated the front
line."
Dr. Miles holds the Croix de
Guerre, the Italian War Cross, and
a citation from the King of Montenegro, in addition to the Congressional Medal of Honor, awarded on
March 6,1919.

Larus & Bro. Co.
Richmond, Va.
Gentlemen:
Two years ago my wife gave me an
expensive pipe. I smoked it a great
deal for two or three weeks, put it aside,
then began smoking it again. This
time it was very strong. Veterans told
me that it had been smoked too hard
for a new pipe and should be put away.
The pipe was laid away again. A
short time ago I got it out and smoked
one of the common brands of tobacco
in it. The results were disappointing.
I told the druggist of my experience
with it. He asked if I had tried Edgeworth. I told him I never had. I followed his suggestion, and I am honest
when I say that it has restored the
sweetness to the pipe, and has made
me wonder. Was it the pipe or the
brand of tobacco that caused me to
lay it away for the long period of time?
As a novice, I prefer Edgeworth. I
am going to stick to it, as I feel satisfied that there is none better on the
market.
Sincerely yours,
Philip C. Shera

Hopkins Archaeologist Finds
Long-Lost Site of Ancient
Greek City

Greece, Dr. David M. Robinson,
professor of achaeology at the
Johns Hopkins University, has
cabled to Dr. Hugh H. Young of
his success.
Olynthus, an ancient city which
was razed by Philip of Macedon
after it had allied with Athens
against him, had been lost to the
world since its destruction, which
occurred about 400 B. C.

Greeks Decide On
Bridge Tournament

"r14

At a regular meeting of the Interfraternity Board last Monday it
was definitely decided to hold an
Interfraternity Bridge Tournament
in the near future. A definite date
will soon be decided upon, for the
beginning of the contest. Each fraternity was assessed two dollars, to
defray the expenses of the tournament. It will be recollected that
the prize, a handsome mantel clock,
was easily won last year by Phi
Kappa Psi, with the team of Hebner and E. Derereaux. The senior
member of this winning combination has graduated and the other
Greeks are anxious to avenge last
year's "walk-away" defeat.
The advisability of holding an
interfraternity smoker was discussed. This question was debated
and referred to a committee to determine the cost and location of this
function. The entire body was in
favor of the celebration, if the cost
is not prohibitive.
A discussion of the possibility of
obtaining the fraternity average for
the past semester and awarding a
scholarship cup upon these results,
then took place.. The amount of
work involved was the chief deterrent, and the matter was laid on
the table until the next meeting.
New delegates for the ensuing
year must be elected by the chapters and will be seated at the next
meeting of the council.

INTERCOLLEGIATE

Last year a certain young lady
enrolled as a student in the University of Montana was requested
by the faculty to sever connections
With their institution. Since that date
a court decision has been handed
down, denying the fair one's petition for readmission. She has now
announced her intention of carrying
her fight for reinstatement to the
United States Supreme Court. The
State Supreme Court has previously
denied her appeal on the grounds
that an educational institution is the
final authority on the control of its
own affairs.

Students residing in the various
dormitories at the University of New
ilampshire have formulated a rather
novel agreement, evidently _with the
improvement of scholastic pursuits
in mind. That dormitory whose
ii?habitants average the .lowest in
scholastic standing at the end of
every term shall be the host at a
dance to be given in honor of its
more scholastically inclined- colleagues.

We were rather surprised the
Other day in the perusal of an article in the student publication of
Dartmouth College. The• writer
zealously urged the various national
fraternities on the campus to return
their national charters and become
local fraternal clubs. Furthermore,
he claimed, that, although belonging

too expensive; while, also, the local

basis of existence for all Greek
letter organizations. We hardly believe that comment is necessary on
the lack of reasoning displayed in
such a statement.

Quite a furore_ has been raised at
Louisiana State University, where
some self-indulgent upperclassmen
took it upon themselves to chastise
the wayward freshmen. Breaking,
of course, university regulations,
that group of students waylaid every
frosh that they could lay their hands

vestiges of tonsorial adornment from

gain more from merely sitting in on
an interesting but easy course than

a difficult subject.

does sound reasonable, but not conducive toward the doctrine of higher
learning which is becoming so
highly emphasized elsewhere and

ASSEMBLY VOTES 248-51
First Inter-class Debate Juniors
Have Won
Marking the first victory of the
class of '29 in any inter-class debate, the Junior team defeated the
Seniors at last Thursday's assembly
in the annual Adams debate contest.
The subject was, "Resolved, That
the United States should not use
armed intervention in Latin-American countries except in time of war."
The Junior team, consisting of
Stewart Brown, Wilmer H. Driver
and Philip W. Ness (chairman),
elected to take the affirmative of this
question. They were opposed by
a Senior team composed of Joseph
G. Blandi, M. S. Hecht and Norman B. Gardiner, Jr. (chairman).
Brown First Speaker

Brown, the first affirmative
speaker, proved that a policy of
armed intervention in Latin-American affairs was detrimental to the
United States politically, economically and morally. This speaker
dwelt mainly upon the political side
of the question, doubting the constitutionality of our acts, and declaring that to all intents and purposes we are at war with Nicaragua
in everything but name. He declared
that any policy averse to the supreme
law of the land brought about tyranny in the government and oppression for the governed."
Blandi, the first negative speaker,
had great difficulty in putting over
his points, and became rather confused in a few spots. He attempted
to trace the history of our movements in the Central American
countries, but was unable to finish,
due to the seven-minute time limit
imposed upon the speakers.
Driver Stresses Economic Side

Driver, second affirmative speaker.
proved that from the standpoint of
the Latin-American countries our
policy was harmful politically, economically and morally. He dwelt
at length upon the economic distress
we had caused to ourselves and to
the nations of Central America by
our policy of "Dollar Diplomacy,"
and went on, stating that though in
some cases we had effected improvements in these countries, yet these
had been at the expense of _liberty
and equality of the oppressed peoples.
•The second negative speaker,
Hecht, was forced to continue the
uncompleted thought of Blandi and
then attempt to correlate the various
improvements with the policy our
government has pursued there.
Time was again his adversary and
he found it impossible to conclude
his arguments.
Negative Rebuttal

Gardiner, who followed with the
negative rebuttal, waived his right
to a short recess and immediately
began his speech, declaring that his
argument was proven if the affirmative had no plan to substitute for the

ABOLISHING ENGLISH COMPOSITION

It has come to our attention that it is the plan of the administration to drop English Composition from -the list of courses
offered to freshmen in 1928-29. This year a partial step in that
direction was taken when entering students were required to take
an examination in composition, which, if passed with a grade of
7.5 or better, served to absolve the student from taking the course.
About one hundred and twenty-five freshmen were required to
take the course.
These one hundred and twenty-five men, with very few exceptions, need the course in composition, and need it badly. The
quality of their work in English, according to the instructors, is
definitely poor.
We can say with assurance that if any of these freshmen were
allowed to receive a degree with their present ability to use the
English language, the University would be distinctly disgraced.
Of course, it is possible that a fairly large proportion of them will
never be graduated, but it is hardly fair either to the men who
will receive degrees or to the University itself to deprive them of
the advanced training in English. It is easy enough to maintain
that they should come to college fully prepared, but if they are
not prepared, it is up to the University to provide the necessary
training.
The present system is perfectly adequate. The men who can
pass the preliminary examination are not burdened with having
to take English Composition, but to assume that all entering
students, regardless of their intelligence or their preparation in
other subjects, are adequately prepared in English, would be a
great mistake. Too many freshmen need English Composition
to permit its being abolished.

It is some time since I resolved to
cease the practice of penning pernicious rot for public perusal, but
after reading an article in the
NEWS-LETTER of February 28, I
feel the urge to enter some sort of
defense of these vile fraternity boys
who hate each other and do nothing but figure. out ways to cut each
other's throats in gentlemanly ways.
The bad feeling between chapters
is easily explained—it is a conceit—if I may use the term of each
individual that he may improve his
own standing by declaiming to the
world at large that such-and-such
is a crowd of loafers, drunks or
what have you. If asked for his
confidential opinion of the same
body he would have no complaint
except, possibly, against a few individuals whom he would hold in
the same contempt, fraternity men
or otherwise.
Perhaps the Alphas are hig-hat
or the Sigmas are drunks—did you
ever consider the fact that the former may have reason for their lofty
attitude and the latter may be able
to pay bootleggers' prices and the
criticism of these groups may be
caused by jealousy?
I am quite sure that the abolition
of fraternities would have no affect
on the present condition, for a man
must have companions, and since it
is obviously impossible to associate
with the entire student body one
must limit himself to a selected
group of men with whom he at least
fancies himself happy. That this
is true is proved by the men on the
'campus who are not affiliated with
any fraternity. They have their
groups and are no doubt influenced
by each other as much as their unfortunate mates who are members
of an organized brotherhood. The
conditions at Hopkins are not conducive to the fostering of a type for
any one fraternity. The real influence in this direction becomes
strong only when the majority of
the brothers live under one roof, eat
at the same table and wear each
other's clothes.
II

HAGERSTOWN VERSUS NORFOLK
In abandoning its Norfolk concert for the trip to Hagerstown
and Chambersburg, the Musical Club has acted very wisely. The
Norfolk trip never had been a success, either from a financial
standpoint or from the point of view of the applause and appreciation received; the Hagerstown and Ch'ambersburg audiences, on
the other hand, were most enthusiastic and supported the concerts
surprisingly well.
It stands to reason, after all, that the smaller towns offer a
more fertile field for the presentations of the club. In the first
place, the annual trip of the Geology I class has established a
reputation for Hopkins students that probably did much for the
Musical Club's cause. In the second place, the relative scarcity
of decent entertainment in small towns gives the club a better
chance to draw large crowds. It is far better to be able to hang
out the "S. R. 0." sign in Hagerstown than to play to an empty
house in Norfolk.

ANOTHER ACHIEVEMENT
Another chapter in the history of the achievements of Hopkins
men has been written at the site of the lost city of Olynthus,
recently discovered by Dr. David M. Robinson, professor of
Archaeology at this University. ; Dr. Robinson, on leave of absence for a year, has made a discovery which may prove to be of
inestimable value to students of Greek civilization all over the
world. The NEWS-LETTER takes this opportunity to congratulate
him in the name of the student body.
The NEWS-LETTER is pleased to announce the election of Gus
Burke, '31, as assistant business manager.

As for the corruption of the campus by fraternity politics—there
would be no less mud thrown or
no better men elected to the various
offices than at present if the elections
were removed from the influence
of fraternities.. Instead of a political deal being made, the hero of the
hour would be elected and he would
be just as incompetent — if not
more so—than our present afflictions. And think of the valuable
experience in fooling the public our
upperclassmen will receive, not to
mention the thrill of believing
they've put one over on the supposedly unsuspecting campus. Let
the boys have their fun.

harm. We pledge allegiance to our

REAL SPIRIT OF WILD WEST TO BE
EXPRESSED IN DRESS AT "POW-WOW"
The Junior POW-WOW, the
name designating this year's fracas, will be held—take heed—on
the Prairie bounded by the ancient
walls of the old Civil Engineering
Building on the evening of March
16. Knives and six-shooters will
be in order as well as popguns and
cap pistols—but machine guns, due
to the Chicago monopoly, are absolutely prohibited.
There is no limit upon the kind
of costume to be worn providing
they smack somewhat of- the wild
and wooly spirit of the Golden
West (See Adventure Magazine).
You can be anything from a prairie
dog to a sunset, or from Chief Pie-

Eyed of the bootleg district of
Moklahoma, Indian Territory, to
Wild Bill Hiccup of two-gun fame.
But, Mah Gawd! Mabel, I
haven't reported to you upon the
tax to be extracted from the exchequer of every cowboy. So boys
get out the pouch of gold dust and
weigh off a few nuggets amounting
to $3.00, provided you will be accompanied by a squaw, or $2.00 if
you intend to fight all by yourself.
And oh! that music—the very
best in town—well little readers if
the broomstick doesn't jump over
the back fence, the bunny gentlemen
will tell you more anon. Pleasant
dreams and read up on "How to Be
a Cowboy" or "What Have You at
the Junior POW-WOW."

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 6, 1928

DR. MILES ONLY MAN IN
STATE TO HOLD C. M. H.
Congressional Medal of Honor
Awarded Professor in 1919
Investigations carried on recently
by several Baltimore newspapers
has revealed the interesting fact
that Dr. L. Wardlaw Miles, collegiate professor of English at Johns
Hopkins University, is the only
man now residing in Maryland who
holds the Congressional Medal of
Honor.
Lead Sally

Captain Miles volunteered to lead
his company in a sally against an
enemy trench near the Aisne Canal
and, while attacking at the head of
his men, was struck five times by
machine-gun bullets. The first shot
grazed him and the second two
were direct hits. Captain Miles
still "carried on" until two more
wounds brought him to earth. Then
he forced his men to place him on
a stretcher and carry him forward
so that he could continue to direct
operations.
"For bravery alone and beyond
the call of duty in action with, the
enemy near Revillon, France, September 4, 1918," Captain Miles was
awarded the Congressional Medal
of Honor by act of Congress.
Dr. Miles was a professor at
Princeton, when war broke out. He
enlisted and was trained at the officers training school at Plattsburg.

Doctors French and Uhler were

favor of the affirmative. A prize of
$50 in books, known as the H. B.
Adams Trophy, was awarded to the
winning team.

to the constitution was offered by
President Blandi. This amendment
provides for representation of the
New Plan students in the first and
second years of the faculty of
philosophy. The constitution as it
now reads.provides only for representatives from the four undergraduate years. This amendment,
inasmuch as it provides representation for an increasingly large number of students, was approved by
the assembly and made a part of
the Student Council constitution.

Hullabaloo Rounding
Rapidly Into Shape
With most of the fraternity material collected and with a large
amount of the senior write-ups and
pictures in, the Hullabaloo is slowly
becoming complete.
Each fraternity has been assessed

FIRE

Drink

In Paris Hospital

Captain Miles first met the enemy
in Lorraine where, during the entire engagement, he calmly smoked
his pipe and surveyed the conduct
of his raw recruits in battle. After
being awarded the division citations
for this action, Captain Miles fell
sick and went to a hospital in
Paris, where he regained his health.
Back at the front once more,
Captain Miles' troops were attacked
and caught in wire entanglements.
It was at this point that Captain
Miles distinguished himself so
nobly.
His citation reads: "Captain
Miles volunteered to lead his company in a hazardous attack on a
commanding trench position • near
the Aisne Canal. Other troops had
failed. His company met with intense machine gun fire, against
which it had no artillery resistence.
Captain Miles cut a passage
through enemy wire entanglements.
He was wounded five times with
machine gun bullets, but instead of
giving up had himself placed on
a stretcher and carried forward to
the enemy trench to direct the company. His courage and inspiration
enabled his men to hold the hostile
position and consolidated the front
line."
Dr. Miles holds the Croix de
Guerre, the Italian War Cross, and
a citation from the King of Montenegro, in addition to the Congressional Medal of Honor, awarded on
March 6,1919.

Gentlemen:
Two years ago my wife gave me an
expensive pipe. I smoked it a great
deal for two or three weeks, put it aside,
then began smoking it again. This
time it was very strong. Veterans told
me that it had been smoked too hard
for a new pipe and should be put away.
The pipe was laid away again. A
short time ago I got it out and smoked
one of the common brands of tobacco
in it. The results were disappointing.
I told the druggist of my experience
with it. He asked if I had tried Edgeworth. I told him I never had. I followed his suggestion, and I am honest
when I say that it has restored the
sweetness to the pipe, and has made
me wonder. Was it the pipe or the
brand of tobacco that caused me to
lay it away for the long period of time?
As a novice, I prefer Edgeworth. I
am going to stick to it, as I feel satisfied that there is none better on the
market.
Sincerely yours,
Philip C. Shera

DR. ROBINSON EXCAVATES
SITE OF OLYNTHUS
Hopkins Archaeologist Finds
Long-Lost Site of Ancient
Greek City
After making excavations to discover the long-lost city of Olynthus,
Greece, Dr. David M. Robinson,
professor of achaeology at the
Johns Hopkins University, has
cabled to Dr. Hugh H. Young of
his success.
Olynthus, an ancient city which
was razed by Philip of Macedon
after it had allied with Athens
against him, had been lost to the
world since its destruction, which
occurred about 400 B. C.

Greeks Decide On
Bridge Tournament

"r14

At a regular meeting of the Interfraternity Board last Monday it
was definitely decided to hold an
Interfraternity Bridge Tournament
in the near future. A definite date
will soon be decided upon, for the
beginning of the contest. Each fraternity was assessed two dollars, to
defray the expenses of the tournament. It will be recollected that
the prize, a handsome mantel clock,
was easily won last year by Phi
Kappa Psi, with the team of Hebner and E. Derereaux. The senior
member of this winning combination has graduated and the other
Greeks are anxious to avenge last
year's "walk-away" defeat.
The advisability of holding an
interfraternity smoker was discussed. This question was debated
and referred to a committee to determine the cost and location of this
function. The entire body was in
favor of the celebration, if the cost
is not prohibitive.
A discussion of the possibility of
obtaining the fraternity average for
the past semester and awarding a
scholarship cup upon these results,
then took place.. The amount of
work involved was the chief deterrent, and the matter was laid on
the table until the next meeting.
New delegates for the ensuing
year must be elected by the chapters and will be seated at the next
meeting of the council.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 6, 1928

INTERCOLLEGIATE
NEWS
Last year a certain young lady
enrolled as a student in the University of Montana was requested
by the faculty to sever connections
With their institution. Since that date
a court decision has been handed
down, denying the fair one's petition for readmission. She has now
announced her intention of carrying
her fight for reinstatement to the
United States Supreme Court. The
State Supreme Court has previously
denied her appeal on the grounds
that an educational institution is the
final authority on the control of its
own affairs.

Students residing in the various
dormitories at the University of New
ilampshire have formulated a rather
novel agreement, evidently _with the
improvement of scholastic pursuits
in mind. That dormitory whose
ii?habitants average the .lowest in
scholastic standing at the end of
every term shall be the host at a
dance to be given in honor of its
more scholastically inclined- colleagues.

We were rather surprised the
Other day in the perusal of an article in the student publication of
Dartmouth College. The• writer
zealously urged the various national
fraternities on the campus to return
their national charters and become
local fraternal clubs. Furthermore,
he claimed, that, although belonging
to a national fraternity does no
harm, it is foolish, unnecessary and
too expensive; while, also, the local
clubs will tend more toward the fostering of friendship, which is the
basis of existence for all Greek
letter organizations. We hardly believe that comment is necessary on
the lack of reasoning displayed in
such a statement.

Louisiana State University, where
some self-indulgent upperclassmen

the wayward freshmen. Breaking,

ASSEMBLY VOTES 248-51
First Inter-class Debate Juniors
Have Won
Marking the first victory of the
class of '29 in any inter-class debate, the Junior team defeated the
Seniors at last Thursday's assembly
in the annual Adams debate contest.
The subject was, "Resolved, That
the United States should not use
armed intervention in Latin-American countries except in time of war."
The Junior team, consisting of
Stewart Brown, Wilmer H. Driver
and Philip W. Ness (chairman),
elected to take the affirmative of this
question. They were opposed by
a Senior team composed of Joseph
G. Blandi, M. S. Hecht and Norman B. Gardiner, Jr. (chairman).
Brown First Speaker

Brown, the first affirmative
speaker, proved that a policy of
armed intervention in Latin-American affairs was detrimental to the
United States politically, economically and morally. This speaker
dwelt mainly upon the political side
of the question, doubting the constitutionality of our acts, and declaring that to all intents and purposes we are at war with Nicaragua
in everything but name. He declared
that any policy averse to the supreme
law of the land brought about tyranny in the government and oppression for the governed."
Blandi, the first negative speaker,
had great difficulty in putting over
his points, and became rather confused in a few spots. He attempted
to trace the history of our movements in the Central American
countries, but was unable to finish,
due to the seven-minute time limit
imposed upon the speakers.
Driver Stresses Economic Side

Driver, second affirmative speaker.
proved that from the standpoint of
the Latin-American countries our
policy was harmful politically, economically and morally. He dwelt
at length upon the economic distress
we had caused to ourselves and to
the nations of Central America by
our policy of "Dollar Diplomacy,"
and went on, stating that though in
some cases we had effected improvements in these countries, yet these
had been at the expense of _liberty
and equality of the oppressed peoples.
•The second negative speaker,
Hecht, was forced to continue the
uncompleted thought of Blandi and
then attempt to correlate the various
improvements with the policy our
government has pursued there.
Time was again his adversary and
he found it impossible to conclude
his arguments.
Negative Rebuttal

Gardiner, who followed with the
negative rebuttal, waived his right
to a short recess and immediately
began his speech, declaring that his
argument was proven if the affirmative had no plan to substitute for the
